results.title: Frontline education kit No.1
results.creator_credit: Frontline Television Productions, ABC-TV (Australia), Santo Cilauro, Tom Gleisner, Jane Kennedy and Rob Sitch
results.brief_description: Behind the Frontline is a behind the scenes look at the process by which a single episode of ‘Frontline’ is put together. All aspects of the pre-production, production and post-production process are examined, from casting to editing. This tape also includes the completed episode. ‘Divide the community, multiply the ratings’ sees a slow news day which is shattered by racial violence in the community, which Frontline is more than happy to encourage - even to the point of cultivating conflict in a televised debate and defying the police requests not to inflame community tension! Roleplay game “Newsflash” and “Frontline” script included.

results.title: Frontline : The search for truth in wartime
results.creator_credit: Central Independent Television (UK), Nicholas Claxton and Ross Devenish
results.brief_description: In this fascinating documentary, distinguished Australian war correspondent John Pilger traces the changing face of war reporting from Crimea through the First and Second World Wars to Vietnam and the Falklands.

results.title: Frontline (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Australian Film Commission, Tasmanian Film Corporation, Australian War Memorial and David Bradbury
results.brief_description: The late Neil Davis covered the Vietnam War for over 11 years; his footage of the conflict was seen nightly by millions of television viewers around the world. The film examines the ethical issues facing a person in the front line who is not an active combatant and provides a record of Davis’ involvement in the conflict, combining his original footage, comments and archival film. Rated: PG

results.title: Frontiers of dreams and fears
results.creator_credit: Mai Masri Productions and Mai Masri
results.brief_description: Powerful, passionate and often disturbing “Frontiers of dreams and fears” tells the heart-breaking story of two young Palestinian girls growing up in refugee camps in Beirut and Bethlehem. Firstly we meet 13 year-old Mona who lives in the Shatila refugee camp, Beirut, Lebanon - scene of the of 1982 massacre by the invading Israeli soldiers, with bombed out buildings, high unemployment and low morale. On the other side of the border lives 14 year-old Manar in the Dheisha refugee camp, Bethlehem, Palestine which is controlled by the Israelis. The film focuses on these two young girls, their daily life, their dreams, hopes and aspirations and their friendship which was born through the internet and letter-writing - activities which are made available for the children within the refugee camps. One of the most poignant moments in the film occurs when groups of children, including Mona and Manar, from both camps are able to meet at the Lebanese/Israeli border separated by fences of razor wire. The emotion, both of joy and of sadness, runs high. It is an extremely moving moment. Many of the children from both refugee camps share their hopes and fears to the camera but one always gets the feeling of the underlying tensions that exist even when at times they appear to be giggling and acting light-hearted as teenagers do the world over. However, the desire to return to their homes and their homeland is strong as witnessed by their music, poetry and writings, the longing of the Shatila children to touch the dirt of Palestine and to treasure gifts of Palestinian soil sent from the children of Dheisha. Award-winning Palestinian filmmaker Mai Masri (Children of fire, Children of Shatila, War generation: Beirut) once again has produced a film with sensitivity and a certain freedom of spirit by allowing the children to tell their stories in their own way. Narrated by Nour Chamoun. For more information see www.itvs.org/frontiers

results.title: Frontiers in space
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and David Bennett
results.brief_description: Exploring the universe with telescopes. Explains how astronomers use optical and radio telescopes to gather information about the universe. Shows the world’s largest reflecting telescope at Palomar Observatory in operation.

results.title: Frontiers downunder
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Frontiers downunder”.
The first in a series of six films depicting life in Australia in the late 1970’s. It is a compilation of some of the footage and subject matter of the other five films, and is a very brief look at the complexities that go to make up this huge southland - the largest island in the world. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Frontier: stories from white Australia's forgotten war: Part two: worse than slavery itself 1830-1860 (A)
results.brief_description: Humanitarians and missionaries begin an anti slavery plight on behalf of the Aborigines against the Crown. Despite their efforts however and a growth in national awareness, the massacres continue.
results.title_for_label: Frontier: stories from white Australia’s forgotten war: Part two: worse than slavery itself 1830-1860 (A)

results.title: Frontier: stories from white Australia's forgotten war: part three: the government should shut its eyes 1860-1938 (A)
results.brief_description: The final part in the ‘Frontier’ series moves North to Queensland where Aboriginal resistance is high. An estimated ten thousand Aborigines lose their lives in the resistance with the law of the day, the Colonial Government, seemingly turning a blind eye. In the face of these massacres, forced assimilation and breeding out, Aborigines started to organise politically and informed white Australia they had no intention of dying out.
